Package moulton.scalable.containers

Class VirtualPanel

java.lang.Object
moulton.scalable.utils.MenuComponent
moulton.scalable.containers.Panel
moulton.scalable.containers.VirtualPanel
All Implemented Interfaces:
ScrollableComponent
Direct Known Subclasses:
ListPanel
public class VirtualPanel
extends Panel
implements ScrollableComponent
An improved Panel class that can be scrolled and can thus hold hidden elements in "virtual space". The VirtualPanel can serve as a Panel parent for any MenuComponent. Keep in mind that the width of child components will be based relative to full width and height of the parent panel rather than just the dimensions.
Author:
Matthew Moulton

  • Field Details

    • fullWidth

      protected java.lang.String fullWidth
      The full width and full height values are the minimum values of the actual sizes of the panel. That is, at render time, if the regular width (shownWidth) or regular height (shownHeight) of this panel is less than the values of full, the rest of the panel can be shown by repositioning, for example, by the use of a scroll panel.

      As said, these values are minimums: if the value of the regular width or height is greater than their full counterparts, this VirtualPanel will fill to those dimensions. This can be very useful if there is a lower bound that a scroll panel should support values under. For example, giving fullWidth the value of "400", scroll bar use will be available only if fewer than 400 pixels are available for the shown width.

    • fullHeight

      protected java.lang.String fullHeight
      The full width and full height values are the minimum values of the actual sizes of the panel. That is, at render time, if the regular width (shownWidth) or regular height (shownHeight) of this panel is less than the values of full, the rest of the panel can be shown by repositioning, for example, by the use of a scroll panel.

      As said, these values are minimums: if the value of the regular width or height is greater than their full counterparts, this VirtualPanel will fill to those dimensions. This can be very useful if there is a lower bound that a scroll panel should support values under. For example, giving fullWidth the value of "400", scroll bar use will be available only if fewer than 400 pixels are available for the shown width.

    • lastFullW

      protected int lastFullW
      Stands for last full width and last full height, meaning the values that fullWidth and fullHeight evaluated to at last render. Used to tell the scroll bar its maximum offset. Set by render(Graphics, int, int, int, int). Not intended to be set directly but subclasses unless rendering takes place.
      See Also:
      Panel.lastWidth, Panel.lastHeight, lastX, lastY

    • lastFullH

      protected int lastFullH
      Stands for last full width and last full height, meaning the values that fullWidth and fullHeight evaluated to at last render. Used to tell the scroll bar its maximum offset. Set by render(Graphics, int, int, int, int). Not intended to be set directly but subclasses unless rendering takes place.
      See Also:
      Panel.lastWidth, Panel.lastHeight, lastX, lastY

  • Constructor Details

    • VirtualPanel

      public VirtualPanel​(Panel parent, java.lang.String x, java.lang.String y, java.lang.String shownWidth, java.lang.String shownHeight, java.lang.String fullWidth, java.lang.String fullHeight, java.awt.Color color)
      Parameters:
      parent - the panel this panel will reside upon.
      x - the x coordinate on the screen, given in menu component value format
      y - the y coordinate on the screen, given in menu component value format
      shownWidth - the component width that will be displayed, given in menu component value format
      shownHeight - the component height that will be displayed, given in menu component value format
      fullWidth - the entire width of the panel. In general, intended to be greater than shownWidth
      fullHeight - the entire height of the panel. In general, intended to be greater than shownHeight
      color - the background color for the box when editable

    • VirtualPanel

      public VirtualPanel​(Panel parent, int x, int y, java.lang.String fullWidth, java.lang.String fullHeight, java.awt.Color color)
      Parameters:
      parent - the panel this panel will reside upon.
      x - the integer x coordinate this panel should appear on its parent panel
      y - the integer y coordinate this panel should appear on its parent panel
      fullWidth - the entire width of the panel. In general, intended to be greater than the shown width, determined at run time by the space on the grid allotted to this panel.
      fullHeight - the entire height of the panel. In general, intended to be greater than the shown height, determined at run time by the space on the grid allotted to this panel.
      color - the background color for the box when editable

  • Method Details

    • render

      public void render​(java.awt.Graphics g, int xx, int yy, int ww, int hh)
      Description copied from class: MenuComponent
      Draws on the graphics object to represent this component visually. When this method is called, the type of panel storing (grid or free) has been taken into account and the dimensions of the space given to this component have been calculated using MenuComponent.solveString(String, int, int).
      Overrides:
      render in class Panel
      Parameters:
      g - the graphics object to draw on
      xx - the x-position on the graphics image that this component's alloted space begins
      yy - the y-position on the graphics image that this component's alloted space begins
      ww - the width on the graphics image that this component is given
      hh - the height on the graphics image this component is given

    • setHeightScrollBar

      public void setHeightScrollBar​(ScrollBar bar)
      Parameters:

    • setTotalOffsofScrollBar

      public void setTotalOffsofScrollBar​(java.lang.String totalOffs, boolean width)
      At render time, VirtualPanel changes ScrollBar.totalOffs and ScrollBar.barOffs of widthBar and heightBar. The values of ScrollBar.totalOffs are set to fullWidth and fullHeight, respectively.

      Use this method to override that setting with another value. ScrollBar.barOffs will be deduced from the value given. Keep in mind that "width" and "height" in this context will refer to fullWidth and fullHeight. Thus, calling setTotalOffsOfScrollBar("width",true) will do nothing. Remember that this may result in a graphical glitch if the equation results to too small of a number because ScrollBar.totalOffs and ScrollBar.barOffs are integers and the latter is a fraction of the former.

      Parameters:
      totalOffs - the algebraic expression string to be solved for at render time for total number of offsets of the specified scroll bar
      width - true:widthBar, false:heightBar

    • getWidthScrollBar

      public ScrollBar getWidthScrollBar()

      Returns:
      the scroll bar associated with this component's horizontal shifting

    • getActiveScrollCoordinates

      public int[][] getActiveScrollCoordinates()
      Specified by:
      getActiveScrollCoordinates in interface ScrollableComponent
      Returns:
      where a mouse scrolling action should affect this component. Normally just its rendering or clicking boundaries. int[0] should hold x points and int[1] should hold y points. The number of x and y points should be equal.

    • getRenderOffset

      public int[] getRenderOffset​(MenuComponent comp)
      The VirtualPanel gets the offset from its parent panel (Panel.getRenderOffset(MenuComponent)), then adds the offset this has saved from the last render, saved as lastX and lastY.
      Overrides:
      getRenderOffset in class Panel
      Parameters:
      comp - the companion to find the render offset for
      Returns:
      a four element long pixel array for interpreting the render coordinates in terms of real locations:
      { xStart, yStart, xEnd, yEnd }
      The first two indices in the array are how far from where the component was told to render the actual render location was. Therefore, if the panel told the component to render at (0,0), but it was actually being rendered at (350,20), the first two values in the returned array would be 350 and 20 respectively.
      The third and fourth values in the returned array signify ending offsets or cut offs. If a component is told to render in the rectangle between (0,0) and (100,80), but only 40 pixels of width and 50 pixels of height are actually being drawn to the screen, then the third and fourth indices would be 40 and 50 respectively. The minimum supported cut off value would be 0 (thus having no true width/height), and negative values are to be interpreted as there being no cut off.

    • getXOffs

      public int getXOffs()
      Returns the number of pixels the position this panel is horizontally offset virtually.
      Returns:
      xOffs

    • setXOffs

      public void setXOffs​(int xOff)
      Sets the number of pixels that this panel should be horizontally offset virtually. Or in other words, when the fullWidth is greater than the shown width, the offset controls what part of the full width is shown. If the offset is 0, then xs [0-shownWidth] will be shown.

      Attempts to set xOffs to negative values or values > fullWidth-shownWidth will be altered to the nearest possible value from [0, fullWidth-shownWidth]. For example, trying to set xOffs = -5 will result in xOffs = 0.

      Updates the getWidthScrollBar() if there is one.

      Parameters:
      xOff - the int value to replace xOffs

    • getYOffs

      public int getYOffs()
      Returns the number of pixels the position this panel is vertically offset virtually.
      Returns:
      yOffs

    • setYOffs

      public void setYOffs​(int yOff)
      Sets the number of pixels that this panel should be vertically offset virtually. Or in other words, when the fullHeight is greater than the shown height, the offset controls what part of the full height is shown. If the offset is 0, then xs [0-shownHeight] will be shown.

      Attempts to set yOffs to negative values or values > fullHeight-shownHeight will be altered to the nearest possible value from [0, fullHeight-shownHeight]. For example, trying to set yOffs = -5 will result in yOffs = 0.

      Updates the getHeightScrollBar() if there is one.

      Parameters:
      yOff - the int value to replace yOffs
